modules.comments:
Graph algorithms for directed graphs.

This module provides a comprehensive suite of algorithms for analyzing
directed graphs, including:

- **Reachability**: BFS-based traversal to find all reachable nodes
- **Topological Sort**: Layer computation for DAGs using `Data.Graph`
- **Transitive Reduction**: Remove redundant edges while preserving reachability
- **Cycle Detection**: DFS with three-color marking to find cycles
- **Connected Components**: Find components treating graph as undirected
- **Strongly Connected Components**: Tarjan's algorithm for directed components
- **Centrality Measures**: In-degree, out-degree, and combined centrality
- **PageRank**: Iterative importance scoring with configurable damping
- **Community Detection**: Label propagation with modularity scoring

All algorithms work with `SimpleGraph`, a simple adjacency-list representation.
Convert to/from `TaskNode` arrays using the conversion utilities.

declarations.comments:
| Simple Graph Representation (Adjacency List)
Simple graph as adjacency list (node -> set of targets)
declarations.title: SimpleGraph

declarations.comments:
| Topological Sort with Layers
A node with dependencies
declarations.title: TaskNode

declarations.comments: A node with computed layer information
declarations.title: LayeredNode

declarations.comments:
| Graph Metrics
Comprehensive metrics about a graph
declarations.title: GraphMetrics

declarations.comments:
| Reachability Analysis
Compute all nodes reachable from a given node via BFS
Uses tail recursion for efficiency
declarations.title: reachableFrom

declarations.comments:
Build a Data.Graph from task nodes
Graph k v = Graph (Map k (Tuple v (List k)))
declarations.title: buildGraph

declarations.comments: Get topological order using Data.Graph.topologicalSort
declarations.title: getTopologicalOrder

declarations.comments:
Compute layers from topological sort
Layer 0: nodes with no dependencies
Layer N: nodes whose dependencies are all in layers < N
declarations.title: computeLayers

declarations.comments: Add layer information to task nodes
declarations.title: addLayers

declarations.comments:
| Transitive Reduction
Remove transitive edges from a graph
An edge A → C is transitive if there exists a path A → B → C
Returns a new graph with only the essential (non-transitive) edges
declarations.title: transitiveReduction

declarations.comments: Get edges that were removed by transitive reduction
declarations.title: getRemovedEdges

declarations.comments: Get all edges from a graph as an array of tuples
declarations.title: getAllEdges

declarations.comments:
| Cycle Detection
Check if a directed graph has a cycle using DFS with coloring

Uses three colors:
- White (unvisited)
- Gray (currently in DFS stack)
- Black (completely processed)

A back edge to a gray node indicates a cycle.
declarations.title: hasCycle

declarations.comments:
Find a cycle in the graph, if one exists

Returns the nodes forming the cycle (in order).
declarations.title: findCycle

declarations.comments: Check if graph is a DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph)
declarations.title: isDAG

declarations.comments:
| Connected Components
Find all connected components in an undirected graph

Note: Treats the graph as undirected (ignores edge direction).
Returns an array of sets, where each set is a connected component.
declarations.title: connectedComponents

declarations.comments: Check if the graph is connected (as undirected)
declarations.title: isConnected

declarations.comments:
| Centrality Measures
Compute degree centrality for all nodes

Degree centrality = (in-degree + out-degree) / (n - 1)
where n is the number of nodes
declarations.title: degreeCentrality

declarations.comments:
Compute in-degree centrality

In-degree centrality = in-degree / (n - 1)
declarations.title: inDegreeCentrality

declarations.comments:
Compute out-degree centrality

Out-degree centrality = out-degree / (n - 1)
declarations.title: outDegreeCentrality

declarations.comments: Compute all basic metrics for a graph
declarations.title: graphMetrics

declarations.comments:
Graph density: ratio of actual edges to possible edges

For directed graphs: |E| / (|V| * (|V| - 1))
Returns 0 for graphs with fewer than 2 nodes
declarations.title: density

declarations.comments: Average degree (in + out) per node
declarations.title: averageDegree

declarations.comments:
| Strongly Connected Components (Tarjan's Algorithm)
Find all strongly connected components using Tarjan's algorithm

Returns components in reverse topological order (leaf components first).
Each component is a set of nodes that are mutually reachable.
declarations.title: stronglyConnectedComponents

declarations.comments: Check if a graph is a single SCC (strongly connected)
declarations.title: isSCC

declarations.comments:
Compute PageRank scores for all nodes

Uses the default configuration (damping factor 0.85, 100 iterations).
declarations.title: pageRank

declarations.comments: Compute PageRank with custom configuration
declarations.title: pageRankWithConfig

declarations.comments:
| PageRank
Configuration for PageRank algorithm
declarations.title: PageRankConfig

declarations.comments:
| Community Detection (Label Propagation)
Community detection using label propagation

Each node starts with its own label. In each iteration, nodes adopt
the most common label among their neighbors. Returns a map from
node to community label (using a representative node ID).
declarations.title: labelPropagation

declarations.comments:
Compute modularity of a community assignment

Modularity measures how good a community structure is.
Higher values (max 1.0) indicate better community separation.
declarations.title: modularity

declarations.comments:
| Conversion Utilities
Convert TaskNode array to SimpleGraph
declarations.title: taskNodesToSimpleGraph

declarations.comments: Convert SimpleGraph to TaskNode array
declarations.title: simpleGraphToTaskNodes

modules.name: Data.Graph.Algorithms

modules.comments:
Layout algorithms for graph and tree visualization

Provides pure layout algorithms that compute node positions.
Works with any node identifier type.

declarations.comments: Tree layout orientation
declarations.title: TreeLayout

declarations.comments: A 2D point
declarations.title: Point

declarations.comments: A node with computed layout position
declarations.title: LayoutNode

declarations.comments: Configuration for layout algorithms
declarations.title: LayoutConfig

declarations.comments:
Compute tree layout with the given root node

Uses a simple recursive algorithm:
- Children are placed side by side
- Parent is centered above its children
declarations.title: treeLayout

declarations.comments:
Layout nodes that already have layer assignments

Useful when you've computed layers separately (e.g., from topological sort).
declarations.title: layeredTreeLayout

declarations.comments: Default layout configuration
declarations.title: defaultLayoutConfig

declarations.comments:
Layout a DAG using Sugiyama-style algorithm

Steps:
1. Compute layers (topological)
2. Order nodes within layers to minimize crossings
3. Assign x coordinates
declarations.title: dagLayout

declarations.comments:
Sugiyama hierarchical layout algorithm

A simplified version that:
1. Assigns layers based on longest path from sources
2. Orders nodes to reduce crossings (barycenter heuristic)
3. Assigns coordinates
declarations.title: sugiyamaLayout

modules.name: Data.Graph.Layout

modules.comments:
Pathfinding Algorithms

Pure implementations of graph traversal and shortest path algorithms.

For visualization-friendly traced variants, see `Data.Graph.Pathfinding.Traced`.

declarations.comments: Result of pathfinding between two nodes
declarations.title: PathResult

declarations.comments:
Result of a graph search from a starting node
Contains distances/depths and parent pointers for path reconstruction
declarations.title: SearchResult

declarations.comments:
Dijkstra's algorithm: find shortest paths from a source to all reachable nodes

Returns distances and parent pointers for path reconstruction.

```purescript
let result = dijkstra (NodeId "A") graph
-- result.distances: Map from each node to its distance from A
-- result.parents: Map from each node to its parent in shortest path tree
```
declarations.title: dijkstra

declarations.comments:
Find shortest path between two nodes using Dijkstra's algorithm

This is the main pathfinding function for weighted graphs.
declarations.title: shortestPath

declarations.comments: Alias for shortestPath (backwards compatibility with A* demo)
declarations.title: findPath

declarations.comments:
BFS from a starting node

Returns all reachable nodes with their depths and parent pointers.
Useful for unweighted shortest paths.
declarations.title: bfs

declarations.comments:
DFS from a starting node

Returns all reachable nodes with discovery times and parent pointers.
declarations.title: dfs

declarations.comments: BFS returning just the nodes in visit order
declarations.title: bfsFrom

declarations.comments: DFS returning just the nodes in visit order
declarations.title: dfsFrom

modules.name: Data.Graph.Pathfinding

modules.comments:
Traced Pathfinding Algorithms

Visualization-friendly variants that record each step of the algorithm.
Use these when you want to animate or visualize the search process.

```purescript
import Data.Graph.Pathfinding.Traced (shortestPathTraced, SearchStep(..))

let traced = shortestPathTraced start goal graph
-- traced.result: the PathResult
-- traced.steps: Array of SearchStep for animation
```

declarations.comments:
Result of a traced algorithm
Includes both the final result and the steps taken to get there
declarations.title: TracedResult

declarations.comments: A step in the search algorithm, useful for visualization/animation
declarations.title: SearchStep

declarations.comments: Find shortest path with tracing
declarations.title: shortestPathTraced

declarations.comments: Dijkstra's algorithm with step-by-step tracing
declarations.title: dijkstraTraced

declarations.comments: BFS with step-by-step tracing
declarations.title: bfsTraced

declarations.comments: DFS with step-by-step tracing
declarations.title: dfsTraced

modules.name: Data.Graph.Pathfinding.Traced

modules.comments:
Graph Types

Core data structures for weighted graphs.

declarations.comments: Node identifier
declarations.title: NodeId

declarations.comments: Weighted edge
declarations.title: Edge

declarations.comments: Edge identifier (ordered pair of nodes)
declarations.title: EdgeId

declarations.comments:
Graph with nodes and weighted edges
Stored as adjacency list for efficient neighbor lookup
declarations.title: Graph

declarations.comments: A path is a sequence of nodes
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments: Create a graph from nodes and edges
declarations.title: mkGraph

declarations.comments: Get all nodes
declarations.title: nodes

declarations.comments: Get all edges
declarations.title: edges

declarations.comments: Get neighbors of a node with their edge weights
declarations.title: neighbors

declarations.comments: Get weight of a specific edge
declarations.title: edgeWeight

declarations.comments: Update the weight of an edge

declarations.comments: Get/set node positions (for visualization)

modules.name: Data.Graph.Types

modules.comments:
Data.Graph.Weighted

Weighted directed graph with efficient forward and reverse adjacency lookups.
This is designed for flow graphs like Sankey diagrams where we need both
outgoing edges (for forward traversal) and incoming edges (for backward traversal).

declarations.comments:
A weighted directed graph with efficient forward and reverse adjacency.

Maintains both forward (source -> targets) and reverse (target -> sources)
adjacency maps for O(1) lookups in both directions.
declarations.title: WeightedDigraph

declarations.comments: A weighted edge in a directed graph
declarations.title: WeightedEdge

declarations.comments: Create an empty weighted digraph
declarations.title: empty

declarations.comments:
Build a weighted digraph from an array of edges.

This is the primary constructor. Nodes are inferred from edges.
For isolated nodes (no edges), use `addEdge` or extend this API.
declarations.title: fromEdges

declarations.comments:
Add an edge to the graph.

If the edge already exists, it is NOT replaced (first edge wins).
Both source and target nodes are added to the node set.
declarations.title: addEdge

declarations.comments: Get all nodes in the graph
declarations.title: nodes

declarations.comments: Get all edges in the graph (in insertion order)
declarations.title: edges

declarations.comments:
Get outgoing edges from a node (O(1) lookup)

Returns array of { target, weight } for edges source -> target
declarations.title: outgoing

declarations.comments:
Get incoming edges to a node (O(1) lookup)

Returns array of { source, weight } for edges source -> target
declarations.title: incoming

declarations.comments:
Get source nodes (nodes with no incoming edges)

In a flow graph, these are entry points.
declarations.title: sources

declarations.comments:
Get sink nodes (nodes with no outgoing edges)

In a flow graph, these are exit points.
declarations.title: sinks

declarations.comments: Get the number of nodes
declarations.title: nodeCount

declarations.comments: Get the number of edges
declarations.title: edgeCount

declarations.comments: Check if a node exists in the graph
declarations.title: hasNode

declarations.comments: Check if an edge exists (ignoring weight)
declarations.title: hasEdge

declarations.comments:
Convert to SimpleGraph (for algorithm reuse)

Drops weights and converts to adjacency-set representation.
declarations.title: toSimpleGraph

modules.name: Data.Graph.Weighted

modules.comments:
Data.Graph.Weighted.DAG

Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) as a newtype over WeightedDigraph.
Provides a smart constructor that validates acyclicity and
DAG-specific algorithms like topological sort and layer computation.

declarations.comments:
A Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) wrapping a WeightedDigraph.

The smart constructor `fromWeightedDigraph` guarantees acyclicity.
Use `unsafeFromWeightedDigraph` only when you know the input is acyclic.
declarations.title: DAG

declarations.comments: Error when attempting to create a DAG from a cyclic graph
declarations.title: DAGError

declarations.comments:
Create a DAG from a WeightedDigraph, validating that it's acyclic.

Returns `Left (CycleDetected nodes)` if a cycle is found.
declarations.title: fromWeightedDigraph

declarations.comments:
Create a DAG without validation.

**Warning**: Only use this when you know the input is acyclic.
Using this with a cyclic graph will cause infinite loops in
algorithms like `topologicalSort` and `depths`.
declarations.title: unsafeFromWeightedDigraph

declarations.comments:
Add an edge to the DAG without cycle validation.

**Warning**: Only use this when you know the edge won't create a cycle.
This is useful for incremental building when you trust the input is acyclic.
declarations.title: unsafeAddEdge

declarations.comments: Extract the underlying WeightedDigraph
declarations.title: toWeightedDigraph

declarations.comments:
Compute topological sort using Kahn's algorithm.

Returns nodes in dependency order (sources first, sinks last).
Since we've validated acyclicity, this always succeeds.
declarations.title: topologicalSort

declarations.comments:
Compute depth (distance from sources) for each node using BFS.

Source nodes have depth 0. Each node's depth is 1 + max depth of its predecessors.
This is the "left-to-right" distance in Sankey terminology.
declarations.title: depths

declarations.comments:
Compute height (distance from sinks) for each node using reverse BFS.

Sink nodes have height 0. Each node's height is 1 + max height of its successors.
This is the "right-to-left" distance in Sankey terminology.
declarations.title: heights

declarations.comments:
Compute layer assignment for each node.

Uses depth as the primary layer (same as Sankey's "Justify" alignment).
This groups nodes that can be processed in parallel.
declarations.title: layers

declarations.comments: Get source nodes (nodes with no incoming edges)
declarations.title: sources

declarations.comments: Get sink nodes (nodes with no outgoing edges)
declarations.title: sinks

declarations.comments: Get all nodes
declarations.title: nodes

declarations.comments: Get all edges
declarations.title: edges

declarations.comments: Get outgoing edges from a node
declarations.title: outgoing

declarations.comments: Get incoming edges to a node
declarations.title: incoming

declarations.comments: Get the number of nodes
declarations.title: nodeCount

declarations.comments: Get the number of edges
declarations.title: edgeCount

modules.name: Data.Graph.Weighted.DAG

modules.comments:
DAG Tree: Tree Layout with Extra Links

A DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph) Tree is a tree structure with additional
cross-links that don't fit the tree hierarchy. This is useful for visualizing
structures that are "mostly hierarchical" with some extra connections.

Examples:
- Git commit graphs (tree + merge commits)
- State machines (tree of states + back-edges)
- The GUP flow diagram (tree + merge arrows)
- Dependency graphs with highlighted cycles

== Design

The tree is laid out using standard algorithms (Tidy/Dendrogram), which
assigns x,y positions to each node. The extra links are then rendered
as paths between nodes using their computed positions.

This keeps tree layout clean while allowing graph-like visualizations.

== Usage

1. Build your tree structure with unique node IDs
2. Define extra links between node IDs
3. Apply tree layout to get positions
4. Render tree edges + extra links

```purescript
let dagTree =
  { tree: mkTree root children
  , extraLinks:
      [ { source: "enter", target: "merge", linkType: "flow" }
      , { source: "update", target: "merge", linkType: "flow" }
      ]
  }

-- Layout tree
let positioned = layoutDAGTree Vertical dagTree

-- Render with Tree API
renderDAGTree positioned linkGenerator
```

declarations.comments:
A tree structure with extra non-hierarchical links.

The tree defines the layout (determines node positions).
The extra links are overlaid after layout.
declarations.title: DAGTree

declarations.comments:
A link between two nodes that isn't part of the tree hierarchy.

These links are rendered after the tree layout is computed,
using the positions assigned by the tree algorithm.
declarations.title: DAGLink

declarations.comments:
A DAG tree after layout has been applied.

Contains positioned nodes and resolved link coordinates.
declarations.title: PositionedDAGTree

declarations.comments: A node with its computed position from tree layout.
declarations.title: PositionedNode

declarations.comments:
Create a DAG tree from a tree and ID extractor.

```purescript
let dag = dagTree myTree _.id
```
declarations.title: dagTree

declarations.comments:
Add a single extra link to a DAG tree.

```purescript
dag # addLink { source: "a", target: "b", linkType: "merge" }
```
declarations.title: addLink
addLinks

declarations.comments:
Apply tree layout and resolve link positions.

This computes positions for all nodes using a tree layout algorithm,
then resolves the extra links to their source/target coordinates.

The layout parameter determines orientation:
- Vertical: root at top, children below
- Horizontal: root at left, children right
- Radial: root at center, children radiating out

Note: This is a simplified layout that doesn't use D3's tree algorithms.
For production use with large trees, integrate with d3.tree() or d3.cluster().
declarations.title: layoutDAGTree

declarations.comments: Get position of a node by ID.
declarations.title: getNodePosition

declarations.comments:
Get source and target positions for all extra links.

Useful for generating path data for link rendering.
declarations.title: getExtraLinkPositions

modules.name: Hylograph.Data.DAGTree

packageMeta.description: Graph data structures and algorithms for Hylograph visualizations
packageMeta.name: purescript-hylograph-graph
